desc: ARID1A, a tumor suppressor involved in transcriptional regulation, is inactivated by mutation in various cancers, including endometrial and bladder cancers.

The ARID1A gene encodes the BAF250A protein, a member of the SWI/SNF chromatin-remodeling complex. This complex plays a role in altering chromatin structure, a process that is necessary for various cellular functions, including transcription, DNA synthesis and DNA repair (PMID: 10757798, 21900401, reviewed in PMID: 25387058). ARID1A binds to DNA without any sequence specificity. However, by recruiting other members of the SWI/SWF complex to DNA, it is thought to confer specificity in the regulation of gene expression (PMID: 14982958, 10757798, 11073988). Germline mutations in ARID1A result in Coffin-Siris syndrome, which is characterized by developmental delay, fifth finger or toe abnormalities, and "coarse" facial features (reviewed in PMID: 11170086). Additionally, ARID1A has been identified as a tumor suppressor in gynecologic cancers (PMID: 21900401).
articles/0/title: A specificity and targeting subunit of a human SWI/SNF family-related chromatin-remodeling complex.
